en.requestHungryPig: Each meal to be 'greater than' the last.
en.requestPickyAlpaca: All meals to be 'smaller than' a certain unit fraction.
lesson_basics: I heard you wanted to become a zoochef?

When we have 'one' of 'something'.
We call it a 'whole'.
Fractions represent equal parts of a 'whole.
The top part of a fraction is called the 'numerator'.
It means how many equal parts 'a fraction has'.
Try changing the numerator and see what happens.

When we compare a fraction with another. 
We use these three operators.
'>' when the left is 'greater than' the right.
'<' when the left is 'less than' the right.
'=' when the left is 'equal to' the right.
Try changing the numerators to see which operators are used.

I'll explain the bottom part later. 
Our first customer is here!
challenge_hungryPig: Your job is to select the right one for each pair of fractions.
When you are ready, click play.
lesson_denominator: You are starting to become a zoochef.
But it's not time to celebrate yet, we have got more customers coming.
Last time I showed you the top part of a fraction: the numerator.
You used the operators to compare fractions with different numerators.
The bottom part of a fraction is known as the 'denominator'.
It means how many parts a whole 'is divided into'.
Now try changing the denominator to see how the whole changes.
Notice how the pizza slice becomes thinner/smaller when the denominator becomes greater.
The greater the denominator is, the smaller the unit fraction becomes.
challenge_pickyAlpaca: Our customer here has a neck that is too thin to eat some foods.
This fraction is the 'biggest' portion that they can eat.
Your job is to select all fractions that are 'smaller than' this fraction.
Keep in mind what it means for a fraction to be smaller.
When you are ready, click play.

This customer is even more picky! 
(Like father like son)
Before we serve him, I need to show you a technique.
lesson_rewriteDenominator: For unit fractions: the bigger the denominator, the smaller the fraction.
But what if the numerator is not 1?
With different numerators and denominators, it becomes much harder to compare normally.
Luckily there is a way to rewrite these fractions so that their denominators are exactly the same.
Let me show you the steps.
For fraction 1, times both the top and the bottom by the denominator of fraction 2.
For fraction 2, times both the top and the bottom by the denominator of fraction 1.
Now that both fractions have the same denominator, it is easier to tell which one is greater.
For this customers, you will encounter many fractions that have different numerators and denominators.
lesson_review: For the Hungry Pig, you compared fractions with different numerators using the 3 operators.
For the Picky Alpaca, you compared unit fractions with different denominators.
Then when the Papa Alpaca customer arrived,
You were able to compare fractions with different numerators and denominators by rewriting them.
I am happy to announce that I have nothing else to teach you. You are now a fully fledged Zoo Chef!
challenge_farmGang: Each member of the 'Farm Gang' eat different amounts.
Your job is to sort the fractions into ascending order for each set of meals.
Assign a fraction to an animal by clicking the fraction, then clicking the box above the animal.
Use any method you like to compare the fractions.
